Description.val:
This line item funds modifications to the Joint Primary Aircraft Training System (JPATS).  JPATS is a joint, United States Air Force led, acquisition program.  Principal JPATS mission is primary training for entry-level student pilots, associated instructor pilots, and primary/intermediate training for United States Navy Naval Flight Officers.  JPATS includes the T-6 Texan II, which is a stepped tandem seat, commercially derived aircraft powered by a single turboprop engine.  

The overall goal of modifications budgeted is to correct discrepancies, deficiencies and obsolescence discovered after the delivery of the aircraft and to commence upgrades to avionic systems for FAA compliance.  Efforts include modifications to address safety, reliability, maintainability, obsolescence, and Diminishing Manufacturing Source (DMSMS) requirements.  Modifications, particularly to avionics systems, may also be driven by new Cyber Security requirements.  

Current (FY 2019) Navy T-6 inventory is 294 aircraft (43 T-6A and 251 T-6B aircraft) with aircraft service life thru 2035.  The Department of the Navy received delivery of final production Aircraft in 2016. Navy JPATS inventory includes 34 Ground Based Trainer System (GBTS) units (7 T-6A and 27 T-6B representative systems).

Justification.val:
The FY 2020 funding request was decreased as compared to PB19 submission due to miscellaneous adjustments. Also additional Operational Safety Improvement Programs were added to improve execution alignment into Physiological Episodes (OSIP 007-20), Avionics (008-20) and Airframe/Propulsion Obsolescence (009-20) Programs. As part of this effort to improve execution alignment, the Department of the Navy commencing in FY 2016, has assumed full spectrum acquisition efforts for certain modifications that will be specific to T-6B aircraft and corresponding cost and schedule updates have been incorporated into this submission.       

Funding in FY 2020 is required for obsolescence, avionics/airframe/propulsion upgrade kits, procurement of avionics upgrade kits required for compliance with Federal Aviation Administration regulations, and to provide support for Joint Primary Aircraft Training System retrofits.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) funds correction of deficiencies discovered during test and evaluation or operational use to the entire airframe, its components and subassemblies, avionics, related Peculiar Support Equipment, and Ground Based Training Systems.  

This OSIP includes modifications to address safety, reliability, maintainability, obsolescence, and Diminishing Manufacturing Source (DMSMS) requirements.  Modifications, particularly to avionic systems, may also be driven by new Cyber Security requirements.   

Correction of Deficiencies Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) include:  Airframe Structural/Sub-systems; Auto Ignition Relay; Flight Management System; Avionics Obsolescence; Onboard Oxygen Generating System; Avionics Hardware/Software Modifications; System Safety Avionics; Controlled Flight Into Terrain Prevention and Crash Survivable Cockpit Voice Recorder; and Safe Arm Handle.  

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: Beginning in PB20 JPATS CORRECTION OF DEFICIENCIES (OSIP 011-04) will be broken out between OSIPs Physiological Episodes (OSIP 007-20), Avionics (008-20), and Airframe/Propulsion Obsolescence to better align with program.

Name.@footnote: 2.6) Other Support:  Automated Dependent Surveillance Broadcast Out modifications that are specific to T-6B aircraft.  Support includes, contracting support and Joint Support costs to the United States Air Force.  Navy also provides support to Joint program acquisition efforts for T-6A aircraft.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Mods:: Installation Name: Install Aircraft Retrofit Kits & GBTS - T-6B

Name.@footnote: FY19 has been updated due to fact of life updates from our Joint Program office.

1.1.2) GBTS Kits (T-6A): Due to different unit costs for the aircraft retrofit and Ground Based Training System (GBTS) kits, a separate GBTS kit line was added to the P3A to price out costs individually. FY19 changes reflect fact of life updates from our Joint Program Office.

Title.val: GRP: Install Aircraft Retrofit Kits & GBTS - T-6B

Name.@footnote: 1.1.3) Aircraft Retrofit Kits (T-6B):  A total quantity of 249 retrofit kits are expected to be procured under this Operational Safety Improvement Program.  Quantity of 2 test articles installed under development efforts are expected to remain on aircraft for a total of 251 T-6B aircraft.   FY19 costs updated to match final awarded contract numbers.

Installation T-6B:  T-6B Installation schedule, grouped, to include both T-6B Retrofit and GBTS kits.  Kits are being bought by Textron Aviation - Defense then Dyncorp International install kits on aircraft.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Mods:: Installation Name: Install Aircraft Retrofit Kits & GBTS - T-6B

Name.@footnote: FY19 cost increase due to additional modified Integrated Avionics Control systems.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) funds upgrades to avionic systems necessary for compliance with Federal Aviation Administration 28 May 2010 release DoT/FAA, 14 CFR Part 91: Automated Dependent Surveillance Broadcast (ADS-B) Out performance requirements to support Air Traffic Control (ATC) service final rule. This mandate stipulates that all aircraft required to have unrestricted access to operate in Classes A, B, and C airspace, certain Class E airspace, and other specified airspace requiring ADS-B Out, must be in compliance with this regulation by January 1, 2020. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  System development efforts for this update commenced in FY 2015, with hardware development costs reflected in R-1 Line #90.  Non-recurring engineering and support efforts to for Engineering Change Proposal development and implementation commenced in FY 2016.

Name.@footnote: 2.1.1) Onboard Oxygen Generating System - Concentrator: Effort migrated from OSIP 011-04. Effort was executed from OSIP 011-04 in FY2018 and FY2019. 42 kits will be modified from -106s to -106A's.  120 kits will be modified -106A's.  Installation will be provided by our Contractor Logistics Service provider, installation is under 50 hours so no installation funding is required.
Previous contract award under OSIP 011-04 will reduce the time to award and produce OBOGS kits

ImplementationMethodName.val: CONTRACT FIELD MODIFICATION TEAM:: Installation Name: OBOGS Concentrator

Name.@footnote: 2.1.2) OBOGS Concentrator Next Generation - Next Generation oxygen generator development executed by Joint Program Office.  Installation will be provided by our Contractor Logistics Service provider, installation is under 50 hours so no installation funding is required.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) funds modifications to the T-6 training system to address aircrew physiological episodes (PE).  PEs have been increasing in number since formal reporting commenced in 2012.  All aircraft systems that contribute to aircrew life support can be causal factors in physiological events.  This includes the Onboard Oxygen Generating System (OBOGS) and all associated piping, valves, and monitors, the Environmental Control System (ECS), engine bleed air delivered to the OBOGS and ECS piping, and aircrew alerting systems to warn of failures.  Modifications to the aircraft will focus on addressing the highest likelihood causal factors for PEs.  These include an Automatic Backup Oxygen System (ABOS) and new next generation oxygen concentrator, new discrete pressure alerting, OBOGS component improvements to reduce pressure loss, ECS improvements to prevent rapid cockpit decompression, cabin altitude monitoring and alerting, and air quality monitoring and filtration. PE Mitigation efforts prior to FY 2020 were funded out of OSIP 011-04 Corrections of Deficiencies.  

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: FY 2020 and out funds provide for non-recurring engineering, kit procurement, and installation in support of T-6 physiological episode mitigation.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) funds airframe and propulsion discovered during test and evaluation or operational use to the entire airframe, its components and subassemblies, related Peculiar Support Equipment, and Ground Based Training Systems.  

This OSIP includes modifications to address safety, reliability, maintainability, obsolescence, and Diminishing Manufacturing Source (DMSMS) requirements.  Modifications, particularly to the airframe, may also be driven by propulsion requirements   

Airframe/Propulsion Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) include:  Airframe Structural/Sub-systems modifications; Auto Ignition Relay; Landing Gear Control Handle redesign; and future propulsion modifications.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Continued service life extension of aircraft by continuing incorporation of Engineering Change Proposals.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Modification:: Installation Name: Crash Survivable Cockpit Recorder

Name.val: 2.1.2) Controlled Flight Into Terrain Avoidance - Organic

Name.@footnote: 2.1.3) Crash Survivable Cockpit Recorder (CSR) kit cost changes are due to quantity buy changes with the USAF and USA.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Modification:: Installation Name: Crash Survivable Cockpit Recorder

Name.@footnote: 2.1.4) Safety System Compliance Retrofit - Quantity includes all T-6A and T-6B. Office of the Chief of Naval Operations (OPNAV) and USAF Joint Program office mandate incorporation of Safety of Flight issues.
2.1.5) Safety System Compliance GBTS - Quantity Includes GBTS for T-6A and T-6B

2.1.8) Avionics Obsolescence: Modifications to the avionics will be required to upgrade the electronic flight instrument displays, Altitude and Heading Reference (AHRS) controller, Midair Collision Avoidance, Military Flight Operations Quality Assurance (MFOQA) and backup flight instruments and those avionic components associated with the affected aircraft systems to include associated software updates. Previously budgeted under OSIP 011-04, starting in PB20 effort is moved to Avionics OSIP 009-20 to better align with program.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) funds avionics upgrades discovered during test and evaluation or operational use to the entire avionics, its components and subassemblies, related Peculiar Support Equipment, and Ground Based Training Systems.  

This OSIP includes modifications to address safety, reliability, maintainability, obsolescence, and Diminishing Manufacturing Source (DMSMS) requirements.  Modifications, particularly to avionic systems, may also be driven by new Cyber Security requirements.   

Avionics Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) include:  Auto Ignition Relay; Avionics Hardware/Software Modifications; System Safety Avionics; Controlled Flight Into Terrain Prevention and Crash Survivable Cockpit Voice Recorder.  

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: Continued avionics extension by continuing incorporation of Engineering Change Proposals.
